titleStmt.title: (0,2) MIRROR SYMMETRY ON HOMOGENEOUS HOPF SURFACES

analytic.title: (0,2) MIRROR SYMMETRY ON HOMOGENEOUS HOPF SURFACES

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this work we find the first examples of (0,2) mirror symmetry on compact non-K?hler complex manifolds. For this we follow Borisov's approach to mirror symmetry using vertex algebras and the chiral de Rham complex. Our examples of (0,2) mirrors are given by pairs of Hopf surfaces endowed with a Bismut-flat pluriclosed metric. Requiring that the geometry is homogeneous, we reduce the problem to the study of Killing spinors on a quadratic Lie algebra and the construction of associated N = 2 superconformal structures on the superaffine vertex algebra, combined with topological T-duality.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Shortly after the discovery of mirror symmetry in string theory, physicists realized that this duality extends to a class of superconformal field theories dubbed (0,2)-models [62]. Unlike the more familiar story for algebraic Calabi-Yau manifolds, the geometric content of these models is given by a pair (X, E), where X is a Calabi-Yau threefold and E is a stable holomorphic vector bundle over X satisfying c 1 (E) = 0, ch 2 (E) = ch 2 (X).

Such pairs are supposed to be exchanged under (0,2)-mirror symmetry, in a way that some of the features of the standard picture are recovered when E = T X [48,51]. For a general E, however, (0, 2) mirror symmetry should be very different [20,49] to the exchange of the A-model with the B-model in the homological or SYZ versions of mirror symmetry [43,58].

At this point a natural question is forced upon us: what is (0, 2) mirror symmetry? An important motivation for this question came with the observation that (0, 2) models have associated chiral rings [1] which generalize the quantum cohomology ring of a symplectic manifold. There has been some direct attempts to understand this picture in the mathematics literature with the aid of toric geometry [10,18], but the story is far from being complete at the present moment. These mathematical advances provide underpinnings for the half-twisted model associated to a (0, 2)-theory [61] -a closely-related but simpler theory which plays a similar role to that of the A and B models in mirror symmetry. According to Witten [61], (0, 2) mirror symmetry exchanges the half-twisted model of (X, E) with the half-twisted model of its mirror and therefore it has the potential to provide an indirect method to understand the chiral rings [50]. This alternative should run parallel Partially supported by the Spanish Ministry of Science and Innovation, through the 'Severo Ochoa Programme for Centres of Excellence in R&D' (SEV-2015-0554 and CEX2019-000904-S), and grant MTM2016-81048-P. The first author is partially supported by MICINN under grant PID2019-109339GB-C31. The second author is partially supported by MICINN under grant BES-2017-080578. The second and third authors are partially supported by MICINN under grants PID2019-109339GA-C32 and EUR2020-112265. to the classical prediction on the number of fixed-degree rational curves on the quintic Calabi-Yau threefold, by Candelas, De la Ossa, Green, and Parkes [14].

The construction of the chiral ring in [10] is based on a general approach to mirror symmetry using vertex algebras by Borisov [9], which is well-suited for understanding certain aspects of (0, 2) mirror symmetry. The idea is that, even though the notion of superconformal field theory which underlies mirror symmetry is not yet properly axiomatized, part of the structure of such a theory is a vertex algebra with an N = 2 superconformal structure, which does have a rigorous mathematical meaning [41] (see Section 3.1). The most basic features of this algebraic object are a vector superspace V and four quantum fields
div.formula: L, J, G + , G ? ? End V [[z ?1 ]],
div.p: whose Fourier modes satisfy suitable commutation relations (see Example 3.2). In this algebraic set-up, (0, 2) mirror symmetry is expected to be an isomorphism of the vertex algebras corresponding to the (0, 2) models of (X, E) and its mirror (X,?), which flips the N = 2 superconformal structures via the mirror involution

The general procedure whereby we associate an N = 2 superconformal structure to a pair (X, E) is not known at present, but it is expected to involve the construction of certain global sections on the (twisted) chiral de Rham complex [47,30], a sheaf of vertex algebras on a smooth manifold introduced by Malikov, Schechtman and Vaintrob. In relation to (0, 2) models, it was proved by Witten that the cohomology of the holomorphic chiral de Rham complex is related in perturbation theory to the chiral algebra of the half-twisted theory [63] (see also [42]).

There has been some progress in Borisov's Programme in recent years, mainly due to the work of Heluani, Kac, and their collaborators [35], but this proposal is far from being complete: even for the case of algebraic Calabi-Yau manifolds, the construction of N = 2 structures on the chiral de Rham complex often involves the SU(n)-holonomy metric provided by Yau's theorem, which we do not know explicitly. For the case of pairs (X, E) the replacement of the metric is expected to be a solution of the Hull-Strominger system [40,57], a fully non-linear system of partial differential equations about which we know very little at present. A novel feature of the solutions of the Hull-Strominger system is that they involve non-K?hler metrics which often admit continuous isometry groups, due to the presence of torsion. Over the years, this has led to the construction of large classes of examples on non-K?hler Calabi-Yau manifolds with an explicit description of the metric (see e.g. [19,52]). Thus, non-K?hler geometry provides a promising scenario for understanding the vertex algebra approach to (0, 2) mirror symmetry. Using the methods from [22], first candidates of (0, 2) mirrors on compact non-K?hler manifolds have been recently constructed by the third author in [23] via T-duality.

Even though the bundle E allows for symmetries, it also carries all sorts of additional difficulties compared to the standard Calabi-Yau case [26,53]. According to physicists, one way to have non-vanishing torsion in the absence of E is to add singularities to the solutions caused by the back-reaction of the geometry when a brane is in place. A famous example is the heterotic string soliton constructed by Callan, Harvey, and Strominger [16] on the non-compact manifold

corresponding to a NS5-brane located at the origin. Near an asymptotic S 3 with flux ? ? N surrounding the fivebrane (the throat of a semi-wormhole) we find a familiar non-K?hler metric: a Bismut-flat pluriclosed hermitian metric. Taking the quotient by a radial Z-action we obtain a compact Hopf surface X with a preferred geometry.

Inspired by this, in the present work we find the first examples of (0, 2) mirror symmetry on compact non-K?hler complex manifolds using vertex algebras. Our examples of (0, 2) mirrors in Theorem 4.18 are given by pairs of Hopf surfaces endowed with a Bismut-flat pluriclosed metric. The quantity ? is realized as the cohomology class of the torsion of the hermitian metric on the underlying smooth manifold, which remains fixed

We will show that (0,2)-mirror symmetry exchanges the complex structure on X with the Aeppli class of the pluriclosed metric of the mirrorX, and viceversa (see Proposition 4.13). This phenomenon is strongly reminiscent of the rotation of the Hodge diamond on mirror symmetry for algebraic Calabi-Yau manifolds. More importantly, in Theorem 4.21 we consider an S 1 -equivariant version of the half-twisted model ? ch X (Q ? ) T 1 following [38,46], and prove that (0, 2) mirror symmetry yields an isomorphism in our examples

The identity is remarkable, as it gives an isomorphism of holomorphic sheaves of SUSY vertex algebras over different complex manifolds. It shall be compared with a fundamental result of Borisov and Libgober [11], which matches the elliptic genera of a Calabi-Yau hypersurface on a Fano toric manifold with the one of its mirror.

The study of (0, 2) models on Hopf surfaces goes back to Witten [63]. Our result confirms physical expectations about mirror symmetry for these models [59]. For the latest developments on (0, 2) mirror symmetry in relation to Landau-Ginzburg models, we refer to [31] and references therein. Alternative proposals to extend mirror symmetry to non-K?hler complex manifolds are due to Lau, Tseng, and Yau [44], Aldi and Heluani [2], Popovici [54], and Auroux and Ward [5,60].

Outline of the paper. Our construction is a round trip, from geometry to algebra and back, and has independent interest in the field of vertex algebras. We start by regarding a Bismut-flat pluriclosed hermitian metric as a solution of the Killing spinor equations D S + ? ? = 0, / D + ? = 0, (1.4) on an exact Courant algebroid over S 3 ? S 1 with?evera class (1.2) (see Proposition 4.6). These are universal equations for a generalized metric, a divergence operator, and a spinor on a Courant algebroid, introduced in [22,24]. Their solutions encompass special holonomy metrics with solutions of the Hull-Strominger system, and are motivated by similar equations in supergravity [13,16]. Identifying S 3 ? S 1 with the compact Lie group K = SU(2) ? U(1) (1.5) and requiring that the solutions are left-invariant, we identify the Killing spinor equations with analogue equations on a Courant algebroid over a point, that is, a quadratic Lie algebra g (see Proposition 4.5).

Basic features of the Killing spinor equations (1.4) on a quadratic Lie algebra g are studied in Section 2. In Section 3, we prove two main results concerning the construction of N = 2 superconformal structures from Killing spinors in the universal superaffine vertex algebra associated to a quadratic Lie algebra (see Example 3.5). For this, we assume that the rank of the generalized metric on g is even (dim V + = 2n), and characterize the Killing spinor equations in terms of natural conditions for a decomposition
div.formula: g = V + ? V ? = l ? l ? V ?

make sense over an arbitrary closed field, and are reminiscent of similar conditions which appear in supersymmetric field theories in theoretical physics [17]. Here, ? j , ? j form an isotropic basis of l ? l. In this generality, in Theorem 3.13 we prove that a solution of (1.6) satisfying a technical condition (2.41) induces an embbeding of the N = 2 superconformal vertex algebra with central charge c = 3 dim l into the superaffine vertex algebra associated to g with level 0 = k ? C. This result generalizes a construction by Getzler for Manin triples [29] (see Remark 3.14). In our second main result (Theorem 3.16), we construct an analogue embedding with central charge

for solutions of (1.6) such that ? is holomorphic (Definition 2.25). We expect similar results for the cases dim V + ? {4k, 7, 8}, in relation to other interesting vertex algebras in the literature [35] (see Remark 2.15 and Section 4.5).

Back to the geometry, in Section 4.2 we construct a family of left-invariant solutions of the Killing spinor equations on the group manifold K (see Lemma 4.8). Applying Theorem 3.16, in Proposition 4.17 we show that any element in the family induces an embedding of the N = 2 superconformal vertex algebra with central charge c = 6 + 6/? on the global sections of the (twisted) chiral de Rham complex. The construction of (0, 2) mirrors in Theorem 4.18 requires the application of topological T-duality [12], combined with Linshaw-Mathai's chiral version of the Cavalcanti-Gualtieri isomorphism [15,46], which realizes the mirror involution (1.1). The identification of the equivariant half-twisted models for (0, 2) mirrors is established in Theorem 4.21, following closely [38]. Finally, in Section 4.5 we discuss an application of Theorem 3.13 to the construction of an explicit twoparameter family of N = 4 superconformal vertex algebras with central charge c = 6. Our construction seems to be related to a N = 4 superconformal algebra originally discovered by Sevrin, Troost and Van Proeyen [56] (see also [13]), but we have not been able to find a precise match.

The names of the equations (2.31) and (2.34) are borrowed from similar conditions appearing in supersymmetric field theories in theoretical physics. In this setup, the structure of the effective potential typically distinguishes two types of conditions for a minimal energy configuration [17], and (2.31) and (2.34) are strongly reminiscent of those.

div.head: Superconformal vertex algebras from Killing spinors
div.p: 3.1. Background on supersymmetric vertex algebras. Here we review basic notions and examples of the theory of supersymmetric vertex algebras that will be needed in the rest of this article. We will use extensively the superfield formalism introduced by Heluani-Kac [36], where details can be found. As we will work only with N K = 1 SUSY vertex algebras and N K = 1 SUSY Lie conformal algebras within this formalism [36, ?4], we will refer to these special cases simply as 'SUSY vertex algebras' and 'SUSY Lie conformal algebras'. The case N K = 1 was studied earlier by Barron [8]. As in the rest of Section 3, we work over an algebraically closed field C of characteristic 0. The adjective "super" applied to algebras, modules and vector spaces will mean Z/2Z-graded.

In the standard approach, a vertex algebra consists of a vector superspace V , endowed with an even vector |0 ? V (vacuum), an even endomorphism T : V ? V (infinitesimal translation) and a parity preserving linear map Y :
(the state-field correspondence) mapping each vector v ? V into a field. By a field, we mean a formal sum
div.formula: a(z) := Y (a, z) = n?Z a (n) z ?n?1 in an even variable z, with 'Fourier modes' a (n) ? End V , such that Y (a, z)b is a formal
div.p: Laurent series for all b ? V , so that the operator product expansions are finite sums
This data should satisfy several conditions called vacuum axioms, translation invariance and locality (see, e.g., [41, ?4.1] for details).
One is often interested in a vertex algebra that is conformal [41, ?4.10]. In particular, the T -action is enhanced to an action of the Virasoro algebra for some central charge c ? C.

When the Virasoro action admits a further enhancement to a superconformal symmetry, it is computationally more efficient to use the superfield formalism. In the case of the (Neveu-Schwarz) N = 1 superconformal algebra, this action includes an odd linear map S : V ? V such that S 2 = T . Adding a formal odd variable ? commuting with z, we can assign a superfield Y (a, Z) = Y (a, z) + ?Y (Sa, z), to each a ? V , with Z = (z, ?), and then the enhanced translation-invariance property is
This motivates the definition of a SUSY vertex algebra [36], which we recall next.

Since S 2 = T , V is a supermodule over the translation algebra H, defined as the associative superalgebra with an odd generator S, an even generator T , and the relation S 2 = T . This superalgebra can be identified with the parameter algebra, i.e., the associative superalgebra L with an odd generator ??, an even generator ??, and the relation ? 2 = ??. The two pairs of generators are denoted ? = (T, S) and ? = (?, ?). Expanding now the superfields
the ?-bracket and the normally ordered product are respectively defined by

The identities (3.4) and (3.5) take place in L ? R, and the identity (3.6) takes place in L ? L ? ? R, where L ? is a copy of L with the formal variables ? = (?, ?) replaced by ? = (?, ?). The degree of a homogeneous element a is denoted |a| (when we use this notation, we are implicitly assuming a is homogeneous). The precise meaning of the expressions in (3.4), (3.5) and (3.6) is explained in Appendix A.

Adding the data given by the second operation in (3.2), one obtains the following definition [36,Def. 4.19]. A SUSY vertex algebra is a SUSY Lie conformal algebra V , whose underlying vector superspace is a differential superalgebra, with the (odd) differential S : V ? V induced by the H-module structure on V , that is unital (with identity element |0 ? V ), quasicommutative and quasiassociative, and such that the ?-bracket and the multiplication of this superalgebra, called normally ordered product
are related by the non-commutative Wick formula. Quasicommutativity, quasiassociativity and the non-commutative Wick formula are respectively given by the following identities:
The meaning of the integrals in these identities is explained in Appendix A.

More precisely, given an even vector J satisfying the identities (3.13) for some odd vector H and an invariant central element c, the triple (J, H, c) automatically satisfies (3.11), so it determines an N = 2 superconformal vertex algebra. This follows by the Jacobi identity for SUSY Lie conformal algebras.

The identity (4.33) is remarkable, as it gives an isomorphism of holomorphic sheaves of SUSY vertex algebras over different complex manifolds. It shall be compared with a fundamental result of Borisov and Libgober [11], which matches the elliptic genera of a Calabi-Yau hypersurface on a Fano toric manifold with the one of its mirror. Here, the term holomorphic stands for the fact that ? ch Xx (Q x,? ) T 1 is locally generated by the T 1invariant holomorphic sections of Q x,? (after parity change) and T 1 -invariant holomorphic functions on X x . Observe that, in the present setup, there is a natural elliptic fibration structure X x ? P 1 and any T 1 -invariant holomorphic function on X x is necessarily pull-back from P 1 . Inspired by [43], one can speculate that there should be a homological version of (0, 2) mirror symmetry for pairs (X, Q), given by a compact complex manifold X and a holomorphic string algebroid Q [25], which replaces (4.33) by an equivalence of suitable categories of vertex algebra modules. To start, it would be interesting to obtain an explicit calculation of ? ch Xx (Q x,? ) T 1 in the present example.

Remark 4.22. The use of generalized K?hler geometry in Definition 4.19 suggests that Theorem 4.18 can possibly be regarded as an example of (2, 2)-mirror symmetry. However, we would like to stress that neither our methods nor the ones from [38] apply directly in the present situation to achieve such result. On the one hand, the generalized K?hler structure underlying (g x , J x ) is not left-invariant, and hence it cannot be regarded as a pair Killing spinors on the quadratic Lie algebra g ? . On the other hand, [38,Theorem 2] only applies to generalized Calabi-Yau metric structures, which are always K?hler on a compact manifold.

A family of N = 4 algebras. In this section we discuss an explicit application of Theorem 3.13. More precisely, we will show that each element of the family of N = 2 superconformal structures induced by Lemma 4.8 and Theorem 3.13 embeds in a N = 4 superconformal vertex algebra with central charge c = 6. Our construction seems to be related to a N = 4 superconformal algebra originally discovered by Sevrin, Troost, and Van Proeyen [56] (see also [13]), but we have not been able to find a precise match.

This seems to agree with the analysis of the Sevrin-Troost-Van Proeyen algebra made in[13, Section 8]. Note also that the value of the central charge c = 6 of our family of N = 4 algebras coincides with the expected value from superstring theory. Proposition 4.24 suggests a generalization of Theorem 3.13 for N = 4 algebras, when dim V + = 4k and G ? = Sp(k) in Lemma 2.14 (cf. Remark 2.15). Here Sp(k) denotes the compact symplectic group. Proposition 4.17. Let K be a compact Lie group and E a left-equivariant Courant algebroid over K. Then there is an embedding

Proof. By Example 3.5 we have an embedding of the Lie conformal algebra SCurg localized at k = 2 into the SUSY Lie conformal algebra R in Proposition 4.15. Furthermore, by the universal construction there is a canonical embedding R ?? H 0 (K, ? ch K (E)). Now, being V 2 (g super ) the universal enveloping SUSY vertex algebra of SCurg of level k = 2, this induces an embedding as in the statement. Indeed, this follows from the following universal property: any monomorphism from a SUSY Lie conformal algebraR into a SUSY vertex algebra can be extended to a unique SUSY vertex algebra monomorphism from the universal enveloping SUSY vertex algebra ofR.

We are ready to prove our main result, which gives our examples of (0, 2) mirror pairs on compact non-K?hler manifolds. Our result is based on two basic observations combined with a theorem by Linshaw and Mathai which provides a stronger version of Theorem 4.11 in terms of the chiral de Rham complex [46].
